sense.name: a flaw or imperfection
sense.commentary: WEAKNESS[+quality][+flaw] Note: implies an imperfection, not a physical fragility (Sense 3)
sense.examples: You must evaluate your product's strengths and weaknesses. The chess master exploited a weakness in his opponent's defense. The weakness of his argument should be apparent.

sense.name: a state of social or political powerlessness
sense.commentary: WEAKNESS[+state][+social][-power][+political] Note: refers to political or social power, not physical or emotional frailty. (Sense 3)
sense.examples: Their party's weakness in the senate means there may not be enough votes for the bill. The withdrawal of troops may be perceived as a weakness in the eyes of our adversaries. The military sensed weakness in the dictator's regime and attempted a coup.

sense.name: a state of fragility, infirmity, faintness
sense.commentary: WEAKNESS[+state][+fragility][+physical/+emotional] Note: implies a lack of strength in some dimension
sense.examples: The patient reported experiencing sudden weakness and shortness of breath. A microphone could help overcome the weakness of her voice. The engineers detected several structural weaknesses in the bridge. The weakness of the radio signal makes it hard to decipher. We felt a weakness in our knees at the sight of the charred bodies. The weakness of her emotional state could be worsened by shocking news.

sense.name: reduced purchasing power of a currency
sense.examples: Will the dollar's weakness attract investors or scare them away? The extreme weakness of that nation's currency is destroying their middle class. Because of the dollar's weakness against the euro, John decided not to travel to France this year.

sense.name: a preference or indulgence for something
sense.examples: Bob has a weakness for tall, blond Scandinavian women. Mary's weakness for double-cream cheeses made it hard to stick to her diet. I have a real weakness for dark chocolate.
